answer_html: Thus, the value of t that gives \(\displaystyle y(t) = 50\) is \(\displaystyle t = 10/3\)
answer_latex:
Thus, the value of \emph{t} that gives
$\displaystyle y(t) = 50$ is $\displaystyle t = 10/3$
hints_html:
(For Solution 1) Using the values of C and k you found in part (a), try to modify the formula \(\displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}\) so that it is written in the form \(\displaystyle y(t) = 100(1/2)^{Kt}\) (where K will be a number different than the original k from part (a)).

(For Solution 2) Using the values of C and k you found in part (a), use the formula \(\displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}\) to solve for t when y(t) = 50.
hints_latex:
\textbf{(For Solution 1)} Using the values of \emph{C} and \emph{k} you
found in part (a), try to modify the formula
$\displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}$ so that it is written in the form
$\displaystyle y(t) = 100(1/2)^{Kt}$ (where \emph{K} will be a number
different than the original \emph{k} from part (a)).

\textbf{(For Solution 2)} Using the values of C and k you found in part
(a), use the formula $\displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}$ to solve for
\emph{t} when \emph{y(t) = 50}.
hints_raw:
'''(For Solution 1)''' Using the values of ''C'' and ''k'' you found in part (a), try to modify the formula <math>\displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}</math> so that it is written in the form <math> \displaystyle y(t) = 100(1/2)^{Kt} </math> (where ''K'' will be a number different than the original ''k'' from part (a)).
'''(For Solution 2)''' Using the values of C and k you found in part (a), use the formula <math>\displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}</math> to solve for ''t'' when ''y(t) = 50''.
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
From part a, we know that

\(\displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{t\ln(1/8)/10} = 100e^{\ln((1/8)^{t/10})} = 100(1/8)^{t/10}\)

Writing as a power of 1/2, we have

\(\displaystyle y(t) = 100(1/8)^{t/10} = 100(1/2^{3})^{t/10} = 100(1/2)^{3t/10}\)

In order for the rightmost expression to give us 50, the exponent needs to equal 1. Thus, the value of t that gives \(\displaystyle y(t) = 50\) is \(\displaystyle t = 10/3\)

From part a, we have

\(\displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{t\ln(1/8)/10} = 100e^{\ln((1/8)^{t/10})} = 100(1/8)^{t/10}\)

Because y(t) represents the percentage of Rhodium-101 remaining at time t, to find half-life (which is when there is 50% remaining), we set \(y(t) = 50\) and solve for t.

\[\begin{aligned} 50 &= 100(1/8)^{t/10} \\ 1/2 &= (1/8)^{t/10} \\ 1/2 &= (1/2^{3})^{t/10} \\ 1/2 &= (1/2)^{3t/10} \\ 1 &= \frac{3t}{10} \\ \frac{10}{3} &= t\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_latex:
From part a, we know that

$\displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{t\ln(1/8)/10} = 100e^{\ln((1/8)^{t/10})} = 100(1/8)^{t/10}$

Writing as a power of 1/2, we have

$\displaystyle y(t) = 100(1/8)^{t/10} = 100(1/2^{3})^{t/10} = 100(1/2)^{3t/10}$

In order for the rightmost expression to give us \emph{50}, the exponent
needs to equal \emph{1}. Thus, the value of \emph{t} that gives
$\displaystyle y(t) = 50$ is $\displaystyle t = 10/3$

From part a, we have

$\displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{t\ln(1/8)/10} = 100e^{\ln((1/8)^{t/10})} = 100(1/8)^{t/10}$

Because \emph{y(t)} represents the percentage of Rhodium-101 remaining
at time \emph{t}, to find half-life (which is when there is 50\%
remaining), we set $y(t) = 50$ and solve for \emph{t}.

\begin{align*}
50 &= 100(1/8)^{t/10} \\
1/2 &= (1/8)^{t/10} \\
1/2 &= (1/2^{3})^{t/10} \\
1/2 &= (1/2)^{3t/10} \\
1 &= \frac{3t}{10} \\
\frac{10}{3} &= t
\end{align*}

completing the question.
sols_raw:
From part a, we know that

<math> \displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{t\ln(1/8)/10} = 100e^{\ln((1/8)^{t/10})} = 100(1/8)^{t/10} </math>

Writing as a power of 1/2, we have

<math> \displaystyle y(t) = 100(1/8)^{t/10} = 100(1/2^{3})^{t/10} = 100(1/2)^{3t/10} </math>

In order for the rightmost expression to give us ''50'', the exponent needs to equal ''1''.  Thus, the value of ''t'' that gives <math>\displaystyle y(t) = 50 </math> is <math>\displaystyle  t = 10/3</math>
From part a, we have

<math> \displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{t\ln(1/8)/10} = 100e^{\ln((1/8)^{t/10})} = 100(1/8)^{t/10} </math>

Because ''y(t)'' represents the percentage of Rhodium-101 remaining at time ''t'', to find half-life (which is when there is 50% remaining), we set <math>y(t) = 50 </math> and solve for ''t''.  

:<math> 
\begin{align}
50 &= 100(1/8)^{t/10} \\
1/2 &= (1/8)^{t/10} \\
1/2 &= (1/2^{3})^{t/10} \\
1/2 &= (1/2)^{3t/10} \\
1 &= \frac{3t}{10} \\
\frac{10}{3} &= t
\end{align}
</math>

completing the question.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 5-11, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions.

5. A sample of the radioactive substance Rhodium-101 decayed to 12.5% of its original amount after 10 years.

(b) What is the half-life of Rhodium-101? Remember to simplify your answer completely.
